Someone used AI to make "restored footage" of the Roman Empire
Did you know, there was at least some level of trade between Bangalore area and Romans at least 1700 years ago?
In 1891, while constructing a railway line in Yeshwantpur, 163 Roman silver coins including ones bearing the faces of Augustus, Tiberius and Claudius were discovered.
In 1965, while constructing a runway at the old HAL airport, a pot containing 256 Roman silver coins was found
For context, the Roman empire fell in 476 CE

Alright! These structures are called Kempegowda watch towers, adapted by the city municipal body in recognition of the city's founder.
Built by Kempe Gowda I, These four watch towers marked the boundary of the city which has now way grown beyond those boundaries. If you're around Lal Bagh, Mekhri Circle, Gavipuram, or Ulsoor, do stop by to witness the history unfold. Also, today marks the mighty Kempe Gowda's Birthday!
So small correction. The towers were built by Kempegowda I's successor, Immadi Kempegowda alias Kempegowda II

The towers were built in 1597
Kempegowda 1 passed away in 1569

Thanks for this Suyash.
right, right. Kempe Gowda II laid these.
 Kempe Gowda I was the founder of BLR.
Unfortunately, a lot of articles do credit Kempegowda 1 for this

POLL:
How familiar are you with the Great Trigonometrical Survey?
OPTION: Know a lot about it (0 votes)
OPTION: Some knowledge (1 vote)
OPTION: Heard of it (0 votes)
OPTION: The what? (2 votes)
Initiated in 1802, The Great Trigonometrical Survey (GTS) was a monumental project undertaken by the Survey of India.
Its primary objective was to measure the entire Indian subcontinent with scientific precision.
This survey played a critical role in the development of modern cartography, geodesy, and contributed significantly to the understanding of the Earth's shape and dimensions.
One of the countless outcomes was the naming of Mt. Everest and the measurement of its height leading to its recognition as the highest peak on the planet
Before this, it was known as Peak XV
Living in Bangalore, some of you may recognise that the VC firm Sequoia India chose to rename itself as Peak XV partners. This is the origin of the name
But the reason I brought up GTS is even closer to home
GTS required the establishment of baselines at various locations throughout the country
A baseline is a permanently fixed reference survey station or point, having known elevation with respect to mean sea level
Te first baseline was drawn between KR Puram and Agara but it was then abandoned due to a technical error
Later, a new baseline was established in Bangalore <This message was edited>
This also included 9 benchmark points and observatories
Till last month, this number was 5
An observatory stood off Hennur-Bagalur Road
It was in a very dilapidated condition
On June 4, this year, a land grabber demolished the entire structure overnight
Really interesting, thank you for sharing

You got this absolutely right
The oldest railway station of Bangalore is the Bangalore Cantt station
To run goods transportation trains between Chennai and Madras
This was just 11 years after the first railway line was opened between Thane and Bombay in 1853
The line specifically ran between Bangalore Cantt station and Jolarpettai station in Madras

POLL:
Those who're new to Bangalore, are you familiar with Onam Sadya?
OPTION: Yes ü§§ (7 votes)
OPTION: Nonam (5 votes)
Ok so Onam is an annual harvest festival celebrated in Kerala.
For fellow Northies, Onam is as big in Kerala as Diwali is up North, if not more
And what I personally love about it is that though the origins are in Hindi mythology, it has become Kerala's state festival with all religions celebrating it with equal gusto
Sadya is the traditional meal that's prepared at this time
It's typically a vegetarian affair and a typical sadya includes 24-30 dishes serves on banana leaf
Some restaurants serve the most amazing Sadya in Bangalore
So I would highly recommend that you explore where good Sadya is being served near you and book a table for this Sunday, Sep 15
Usually costs around 1000-1800 /head depending on the place. Takeaway is a bit cheaper than dine-in <This message was edited>

For Koramangala folks, some good options are:
1. Moplah's
2. Kappa Chakka Kandari
3. Indian Coffee House

Indiranagar:
Coracle cafe in BIC are serving
There are many places in every locality which provide this so explore and book a place or takeout in advance as these slots runs out very quickly <This message was edited>
And be prepared for a major food coma post the meal

I took the lazy way out
Oldest Durga Puja at Bengali Club Kashmere Gate

When women, old and young, in sarees, outnumber men while riding the escalator at metro station, you correctly conclude that it is festival time. And not just any regular festival, but the Durga Puja. 
On the auspicious day of Navami, I went Pandal hopping, from the oldest Durga Puja at the Bengali Club, to many others in the region of CR Park, Kali Bari and Rama Krishna Ashram. 
The traditional dress discipline followed by the elders in form of bright and flowy sarees of women, and simply embroidered bengali kurtas has been turned on its head by the woke generation. The fairer sex wore pastel shades, with elegant ethnic and geometric patterns and understated jewellery, the men adorned rather garish, dazzling, scintillating, irridescent, sequined kurtas of varying length and material, from see-through crocheted to heavily ornate shades of royal blue, blood red, magenta and even shocking pink.
Other than this glaring reversal, what was on display?
The show of hands, that went up in the air as purohits chanted the mantras, not with devotion, but to click the photographs at the right moment.
Tradition isn't what it used to be, or may be it is. 
Who cares!
Enjoy the festival!!!
My observation of the various spots
The high point was watching five theatrical productions in Delhi, including a Ramleela that is now in its 68th year
So much jealousy is happening right now
If it offers any solace, I have come here after more than a year, and will return to Namma Bengaluru tomorrow
I haven't been to Delhi in years

I cut my teeth into theatre and heritage only in Delhi, and built strong friendships during the two years I spent here, pre Covid. So despite the pollution, and despite the chaos on the roads, Delhi remains the city of my heart, and I try to visit each year
I always get a high hereüòù

Hi All,

Thanks to Suyash for adding me here.

I am Sunil Pichamuthu here.
A 4th generation Bangalorean and IT professional
My Bangalorean background in brief:
My great grandfather was the first Indian Headmaster of Wesleyan Mission School where Sir Mirza Ismail was one of his students.
My grandfather was Dr. C. S. Pichamuthu a geologist who scientifically proved that parts of then Mysore State was formed under the sea.
My father is Dr. J P Pichamuthu who developed the indigenous runway visual range assessment system for airports called AVRA now branded as Drishti.

I had presented a plan to the BBMP on tunnel roads in 1999-2000 after approaching the then CM S M Krishna.
An article on tunnel roads was published in the The Hindu on 28 January 2001.

I used to actively blog at https://sunilpichamuthu.blogspot.com 

I am also interested in Bangalore history and have written two booklets on the history of St. Mark's Cathedral on MG Road and also conducted a history walk around that church.
Welcome to Bengaluritage Sunil. Wonder to have you among us

Where can we get our hands on your booklets?

Today my birthplace i.e. Agra, lost the last remaining monument credited to Mumtaz Mahal, to disrepair
This was the corner Burj of Jahanara Bagh
Pic 1 and Pic 3 are before pictures
Pains me so much, it's tough to express in words
But we live in a country where most educated people still don't give a flying f*** about our history and heritage
People don't care, some won't, many can't afford to
I really don't expect anyone to be obsessive about history like me. But even basic respect for history is too much to ask
Agra is my ancestral place too, and the people are the reason why I absolutely abhor going there
It's also looking like active damage was given to both places
It's my native place too and I know exactly what you're talking about
Heritage is kept alive bh the people around it, not by government. ASI doesn't have the budget or the gumption
Absolutely possible. When there's no protection, people often tend to chup away material or take away bricks to reuse in personal construction and repairs
Agra,as per SM Latif 's book had 300 mansions on the river bank, not one stands today
Happened to the bricks from indus valley civilisation. We are the land of vandals
Correct. Most locals aren't aware of the local monuments outside of Taj, Agra fort, Sikandra and maybe Itmad-ud-daula
Been happening for centuries. It's just so frustrating that it continues in the 21st century, in a city which literally houses a wonder of the world
Locals are obsessed with themselves and everyone around them, it will require brain transplantation into them to become aware of important things in life
And frankly, about some monuments I am actually happy that they are blissfully ignorant, e.g. jhunjhun katora in the court complex, the cemetery opposite it
So true. I feel the same about the Roman Catholic Cemetery, Chini ka rauza, etc. there
Red Tajmahal, Samru's grave are really resting there while chaos prevails metres away from them <This message was edited>
It's the tomb of Col John William Hessing, built by his wife at Agra's Roman Catholic Cemetery in 1803 after he died in a military engagement.
He was a mercenary and was serving the Marathas who ruled Agra at the time of his death
But this cemetery is a wonder in itself.
It's one of the oldest Christian cemeteries in North India
Started off as an Armenian Christian Cemetery
If I remember correctly, the oldest grave is from 1550
There's even this one grave which states that the person met Akbar in his court
Oh and credits to Heritage Hindustan for the 4 pics of the minaret
It looks like Islamic architecture even though it's a tomb of Christians
It was meant to be a red sandstone imitation of Taj

This reminded me of this  fact I recently learnt - earlier, Christian prayers used to be similar to Muslim prayer (bowing head and touching to ground) - 

https://youtu.be/m_kiEMIaVsM
Mrs Hessing chose this design for the final resting place of her valiant husband

Not much is documented about it, but it is believed to have been built by Humayun to honour the water carrier who saved his life . The name is attributed to the tinkling sound that heralded the arrival of bhishtis (water carriers) and its dome resembling an inverted bowl

Gustav Hermann Krumbiegel was a German botanist who is credited with greening Bangalore
He was born in 1865 near Dresden
Just saw this.. could have joined you.. maybe some other time
He moved to India in 1893 as curator of the botanical gardens in the princely state of Mysore
Closer to home, he was chiefly responsible for mass planting of trees and creating gardens in Bangalore
Much of Lalbagh, and Ooty Botanical Garden that you see today is thanks to him
He was the mind that built Brindavan Gardens in Mysore <This message was edited>
He planted different sets of trees in Bangalore so some trees would always be in bloom at any point in the year in Bangalore, "an eternal spring"
He ended up spending the majority of his life in India
Twice, first in WW I and then in WW II, he was interned in camps for being German
He passed away in 1956 and is buried in the Methodist Cemetery on Hosur Road

*You‚Äôre Invited: Walk through the Bangalore Cantonment - The Army Town and listen to its tales!*

Join us for a specially curated walk through the heart of Bangalore‚Äôs colonial past. This experience will uncover the city‚Äôs military roots, the rise of the finest Cantonment and the life within it.

One of our hosts, a philatelist and an Indian military history enthusiast offers an interesting overview into Bangalore‚Äôs military culture.

We‚Äôll walk through one of India‚Äôs most significant and finest Cantonment. A posting at Bangalore was highly sought after by the British officers .

üìÖ When? 14 June 2025 at 7:30 AM
üìç Where? MG Road (exact location will be shared after registration)
üí∞ How much? ‚Çπ2500 per person
Includes: Expert-led walk, breakfast at The Ceylon Tea Room, refreshment, souvenir, and more!

On this trail, we‚Äôll explore the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù and ‚Äúhow‚Äù Bangalore was chosen as a Cantonment town, and how it quickly rose to become a celebrated military hub in the country.

This is not just a walk. It‚Äôs a deep dive into stories, structures, and timelines that shaped a very unique part of Bangalore.

Together, we will:
‚Ä¢	Trace the evolution of the Cantonment, from its early barracks to today‚Äôs MG Road
‚Ä¢	Walk past heritage buildings and former landmarks that shaped this neighbourhood
‚Ä¢	Explore rare archival photographs, maps, postcards, and 19th-century letters
‚Ä¢	Learn about postal, food, and beverage history that reveals how people lived then
‚Ä¢	Connect the dots between the past and present with narratives that bring it all alive

We begin our walk on MG Road, followed by breakfast at a restaurant with a story and a view, then continue onward to Cubbon Road and beyond.

: Press Release::

: Date: 77th Independence Day to be celebrated on 15-08-2025:

For the first time, an E-Pass system has been provided for the state-level 77th Independence Day celebration program to be held at the Field Marshal Manekshaw Parade Ground in Bengaluru on 15-08-2025. The public interested in watching the said program can obtain an E-Pass from the Seva Sindhu website (www.sevasindhu.karnataka.gov.in). To obtain an E-Pass, they must register on the Seva Sindhu website by entering their Aadhaar card details and after logging in to the website and entering their mobile number, they can download the E-Pass by entering the OTP received. This is an announcement for the public's awareness.

Special Note:-

> E-pass is valid only on 15-08-2025.

> E-pass holders must enter the premises near Gate No. 4 before 08:15 AM. Entry will not be allowed after this time and the e-pass will be considered invalid.

Each e-pass allowed only one person to enter.

It is mandatory to carry a printed copy or digital (mobile) copy of the e-pass during the event.

> Children below 6 years of age do not require an e-pass.

> E-pass is not transferable.

> E-passes are limited to a total number of 3000, so priority will be given on a "first come, first served" basis.

> Original ID card is compulsory.

> Parking facilities will not be provided to e-pass holders.

> The owners are responsible for the parking system. <This message was edited>

Press release

Independence Day: Raj Bhavan for three days from August 16

Open to public viewing

On the occasion of the 79th Independence Day, the Raj Bhavan will be open to the public for a total of three days on 16, 17 and 18 August 2025, from 6 pm to 7:30 pm on all three days.

The public coming to view the Raj Bhavan must carry a government-issued/clearly photographed ID card. It is mandatory to undergo security checks upon entry to the Raj Bhavan. No entry should be made within the premises of the Raj Bhavan other than the places allowed for viewing. The public must follow the advice/instructions given by the security officers and staff during and after entry. The public must cooperate by maintaining peace and quiet within the premises of the Raj Bhavan.

Special instructions: During the entry of the public to the Raj Bhavan

Mobiles, laptops, cameras and all types of electronic devices are completely prohibited. Sharp objects and all types of metal objects, snacks, plastic items, matches, lighters, all types of bags and handbags, tobacco and alcoholic products are completely prohibited and public vehicles are not allowed to enter the Raj Bhavan.

Travelling Plants is a transdisciplinary project initiated by the Goethe-Institut Chennai, in collaboration with the Alliance Fran√ßaise of Madras and the Institut Fran√ßais de Pondich√©ry. The Exhibition, comprising four artistic positions, curated by Lina Vincent, journeyed through Chennai, Pune, Hyderabad, New Delhi, and Colombo, enhanced by fresh local input at each station.

Bangalore itself is a living archive of plant migration.

The Charbagh of Lalbagh, envisioned by Hyder Ali and Tipu Sultan, once echoed the gardens of Persia.

The British seeded the city with exotic species, seeking shade and ornament, while the German horticulturist Gustav Hermann Krumbiegel and others imagined horticultural futures that still unfold today.

In this Exhibition, the artists curated by Suresh Jayaram follow the echoes of these botanical journeys, exploring stories of migration and memory, displacement and resilience. Plants here are protagonists and keepers of histories, witnesses to exchange, exploration and exploitation.
